# Biden's Isolation Deepens As Doubters' Ranks Grow

## Even Some of His Own Aides Are Weighing How to Persuade Him to Drop Out

This article is by Michael S. Schmidt, Katie Rogers and Peter Reuter

WASHINGTON — President Biden found himself increasingly isolated on Thursday as a small group of his longtime aides and advisers have become convinced that he will have to make what they see as the painful but inevitable decision to abandon his campaign for re-election, according to three people who have been briefed on the matter.

In recent days, the group has been trying to come up with ways to persuade Mr. Biden to step aside from the campaign. Those discussions were recorded by three people familiar with them who, like others in this article, spoke on the condition of anonymity to discuss a sensitive interview. There is no indication that any of the discussions have reached Mr. Biden himself, one of the lawmakers told me.

The effort came after a disastrous debate performance in Montana two weeks ago planned by Mr. Biden's candidacy into crisis. In a filing requested from an independent counsel, the Republican campaign told reporters that the candidate was not outright cold to him on the subject, and then calls were being echoed by some of the weakest links in the party.

At the center of it all is Mr. Biden, who is convinced that he is the only one who can bear former President Donald J. Trump, so

The small group of Mr. Biden's advisers in the administration and the Republican party said they are whom have told aides that they do not want to be shunted back to try to run for a second term — and that they are willing to consent to a president of several things for him now.

They said they would have to leave the race but the campaign said Trump, Mr. Trump, would have to convince him that another candidate, like Vice President Mike Pence, could beat Mr. Trump. And they would have to convince Mr. Biden that, despite his age, the process to choose an
